Molecular Catalysis, 68 (1991) 53-71 53 The adsorption of 02 and NO on CrOx/Zr02 catalysts, as investigated by IR and ESR spectroscopies Valerio Indovina*, Dante Cordischi, Sergio De Rossi, Giovanni Ferraris Centro SACSO (CNR), Dip. Chimico, Universita La Sapienza, 00185 Rome (Italy) Giovanna Ghiotti and Anna Chiorino Dip. Chimica Inorganica, Chimica Fisica a Chimica dei Materials, Universita di Torino, Turin (Italy) (Received October 22, 1990; accepted December 20, 1990) Abstract The adsorption of OZ at 195 K and that of NO at 298 K on CrO./Lr02 samples have been investigated by the double isotherm method. The nature of the surface species formed before and after adsorption has been studied by means of IR and ESR spectroscopies. Prior to OZ or NO adsorption, CrOs/Zr02 samples were heated in OZ at 773 K (average oxidation number of Cr, n=5.5) and reduced with CO at 423 to 623 K to controlled extents (n=5.5 to 2.5). The results show that the adsorption of OZ at 195 K oxidizes to Cr(VI) the Cr(II) present in the sample after the reduction. The oxidation of Cr(II) to Cr(VI) is quantitative and nearly selective. Only a small fraction of Cr(III), also present in the reduced sample, is oxidized to Cr(V) (ESR, y-signal). The adsorption of NO on the sample heated in OZ yields mono- and dinitrosyls of Cr(III), arising from the reduction of Cr(V). The reduction of Cr(V) to Cr(III) is evidenced by both ESR and IR data. The adsorption of NO on the reduced sample (n=2.5) leads, on average, to 1.7 to 2.0 NO molecules adsorbed per Cr atom. In the same conditions, dinitrosyls and mononitrosyls of Cr(II) and Cr(III) are formed, in addition to N20 and nitrites (and/or nitrates). Upon evacuation of the latter sample at 423 K, the adsorbed NO oxidizes most of the Cr(II) to Cr(VI) (n=4.2) and, in fact, the nitrosyls of Cr(III) are the only species detected by IR on NO re-admission after the evacuation treatment. Blank experiments on pure Zr02show that the dismutation of NO leading to NZO and nitrites (and/or nitrates) takes place on sites of the Zr02 support. When the reduced sample is further reacted with HZO at 853 K, only the dinitrosyls and mononitrosyls of Cr(III) are detected upon exposure to NO, since the reaction with H20 at 853 K selectively oxidizes the Cr(II) to chromia-like species. It is suggested that coordinatively unsaturated Cr(III) ions, two vacancies at least on IR evidence, are the active sites for the hydrogenation of propene and H2-D2 equilibration reactions, previously investigated on the same CrO,,/Zr02 catalysts. Introduction Chromium-containing systems, mainly supported on Si02 [ 1 ] or A1203 [2], have been extensively investigated as catalysts for hydrogen-involving *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/91/$3.50 1991- Elsevier Sequoia, Lausanne 54 reactions (H2-D2 [31 and hydrogenation of propene [41). The same catalysts have been also characterized by various techniques including ESR [5-71 and IR [8J. Reasons for studying chromia supported on zirconia, and specifically their interest for catalytic reactions such as hydrogenations and dehydrogenations, have been illustrated in previous work [9, 101. In a recent paper, the nature of the chromium species present on the surface of CrO.,/ZrO2 catalysts has been investigated by ESR and IR, mainly using the adsorption of CO at RT as a probe [ 101. The work has shown that the oxidized CrO.,/ZrO2 catalysts contain Cr(VI) and Cr(V) in nearly equal amounts (average oxidation state of Cr, n = 5.5). Specifically, after heating the samples in OZ at 773 K, the following species were observed: (i) polynuclear chromium species (VI) and (V), (ii) chromates and (iii) isolated Cr(V), the latter species being identified through the ESR signal of 53Cr enriched samples (Cr(V), y-signal). Upon reduction to controlled extents (n = 5.5 to 2.5) with CO at increasing temperatures (423 to 623 K), isolated Cr(V) was found to be preferentially reduced to Cr(III) in the early stages of the reduction and, thereafter, Cr(VI) also was reduced to Cr(II), as monitored by the relative intensity of the IR bands arising from the carbonyls of Cr(III) and Cr(II) and the intensity of the Cr(V) y-signal. On the whole, two independent redox couples were identified on the surface of the CrO.,/ZrO2 samples: Cr(VI)/Cr(II) and Cr(V)/Cr(III). In the present investigation the adsorption of OZ at 195 K and that of NO at 298 K were studied volumetrically (by means of the double isotherm method, as proposed by Weller [ 111), and by IR and ESR experiments performed before and after adsorption. The study was directed to gain information on (i) the dispersion of chromium on Zr02, (ii) the coordinative unsaturation of Cr(II) and Cr(III) on this matrix, (iii) to assess the redox processes taking place on the CrO.,/ZrO2 system with OZ and NO at low temperature and, finally, (iv) to gain a better insight into the nature of sites active in H2-D2 and propene hydrogenation reactions, previously investigated on the same catalysts [9, 121. Experimental Materials Catalysts were prepared and characterized as previously described [9, 10, 13]. Here it is sufficient to recall that the zirconia support was obtained from a hydrous zirconium oxide prepared by the hydrolysis of zirconium oxychloride, dried at 383 K and calcined at 673 and 773 K. The two preparations, labelled Z(673) and Z(773) respectively, were thereafter placed in contact with a chromium trioxide solution at pH=1, filtered and, finally, dried at 383 K before their use in the various experiments. CrO_-/Zr02 catalysts are designated as ZC followed by a figure giving the approximate Cr content and, in brackets, the calcination temperature (K) of the Zr02 used for the impregnation. Two catalysts were mainly used for the work reported in the 55 present investigation: ZC1.6(673), Cr(wt 90)= 1.60, SA=117 m2 g-', surface concentration= 1.6 Cr atoms rim-', and ZC0.8(773), Cr(wt.sso)=0.81, SA=52 m2 g-', surface concentration= 1.8 Cr atoms nm-2. CO (SIO, 99.995ss'o) and OZ (SOL, 99.95%) were dried by passing them for 10 min through traps at 77 K before admission to the reaction chamber for either adsorption experiments or redox cycles. NO (SIO, 99.95%) was further purified by repeated vacuum distillation at 145 K. Distilled H20 was placed in a Pyrex bulb and purified by evacuation at 298 K, followed by a freeze-pump-thaw method to remove dissolved gases. Procedure For the adsorption and ESR experiments, the activation of the samples was performed in an all-glass circulation apparatus equipped with a magnetically driven pump. The catalyst (0.3 to 0.5 g) was placed in a silica adsorption chamber equipped with a side ESR tube. Samples were generally submitted to standard redox cycles consisting of (i) heating with OZ at 773 K for 0.5 h (standard oxidation, s.o.) and (ii) reduction with CO at 423 to 623 K. The gas pressure was measured by means of a pressure transducer (MKS Baratron, sensitivity 10-2 torr). The extent of the reduction was controlled through the CO consumed and/or the CO? produced during the reduction itself. Specifically, the acquisition or loss of electrons expressed as a/Cr (number of electrons) /(total Cr atoms) allowed the variation of the average oxidation number, n, to be followed. The n values measured during redox cycles reported in the present paper are in substantial agreement with those measured previously on the same (or similar) catalysts to which reference can be made for details [ 9, 10, 13 ]. In particular, n = 5.5 was measured after s.o. and decreased to as low as 2.5 after reduction to various extents. The adsorption of NO at 298 K and that of OZ at 195 K were performed according to the double isotherm method, as proposed by Weller [ 11 ]. The amount of the adsorbed gas (OZ or NO) is given as molecules rim -2 or as molecules (NO or OZ) per total Cr atoms (NO/Cr or OZ/Cr). In particular, after the determination of a first isotherm on the ZC sample reduced to the desired extent, the sample was evacuated for 0.5 h at the adsorption temperature and a second isotherm was measured. The amount of gas adsorbed during the first isotherm, obtained by extrapolation at p = 0, will be referred to as `total adsorption', the amount determined during the second isotherm as `reversible adsorption', and the difference (in that order) as the `irreversible adsorption'. After reduction to the desired extent and/or after adsorption experiments, the powder was transferred to the ESR tube and the spectrum recorded. ESR measurements were generally made at RT or at 77 K on a Varian E9 spectrometer operated at X-band frequencies. The spectrometer was equipped with an on-line computer for data treatment. Absolute concentrations of Cr species contributing to the ESR spectra were obtained from the integrated area by using a Varian strong pitch with linear spin density, 3 X 1015 spin cm-1, as a standard. Due to the nature of the standard, the accuracy in 56 absolute spin determination was 20%; however, the variations of relative intensities of the Cr(V) y-signal could be determined with an accuracy of better than 5%. IR spectra were run on an FT-IR spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer 1760-X), with a resolution of 2 cm-I. The powdered samples were pelleted (pressure, 20 x 103 kg cm-2) in self-supporting discs of about 230 mg cm-2 mm-' and put in an IR cell which allowed for thermal treatments in vor in a controlled atmosphere. ESR data After s.o. of the ZC0.8(773) sample, a strong axial signal (g =1.953 and g1=1.978) is the only species detected by ESR spectroscopy (y-signal). The signal is the same as previously observed on the Zr02 support [9, 10, 14 ] and on other supports [5-7 ],and is assigned to Cr(V). Previous experiments with the 53Cr isotope, as already mentioned in the Introduction, allowed assignment of the signal on Zr02 to mononuclear Cr(V) species and specifically to surface chromyl complexes in a square pyramidal configuration [ 10, 141. The molar fraction of Cr(V) (Cr(V)/Crtj detected on the s.o. ZC0.8(773) sample was 0.24. However, relying on the facts that (i) only Cr(V) and Cr(VI) species are present in the s.o. ZC samples (ESR, IR and XPS evidence [9, 101), (ii) n = 5.5, and (iii) the ESR detection is limited to non-interacting Cr(V) species, it was previously estimated that the molar fraction of Cr(V) is - 0.5 in all ZC samples after the s.o. treatment [9, 101. Therefore, the value of NO/Cr=0.9 obtained on the s. o. sample must be regarded with caution, being probably overestimated. ESR Oa The concentration of chromium species detectable by ESR has been measured on the ZC0.8(773) sample, before and after the adsorption of NO. After the s.o. treatment, Cr(V) is the only species detected by ESR, as already mentioned. Upon adsorption of NO at RT, a decrease in the intensity of the Cr(V) signal is observed and, simultaneously, an ESR signal from Cr(RI) is detected. The latter is the S-species (a very broad signal, AHPp = 3000 G centered at g = 2, with a broad maximum at g in the range 3.8 to 5.0) previously observed in the reduced ZC samples and assigned to weakly interacting Cr(III) ions exposed on the surface of Zr02 [ 10, 14 [. Subsequently, when the sample is evacuated at increasing temperature, the intensity of the Cr(V) signal progressively increases while that of Cr(III)-8 progressively decreases. In particular, after evacuation at 473 K, the Cr(V) signal is restored to its initial intensity whereas the Cr(III)-8 signal is absent. 60 As for the adsorption of NO on the reduced sample (CO at 623 K, n = 2.5), Cr(III)-8 is the only species detected by ESR after such treatment. The results show that (i) the Cr(III)-8 is almost unaffected by the exposure to NO and (ii) the Cr(V) signal, absent in the reduced sample, is now detected. Upon subsequent evacuation, the intensity of the Cr(V) slightly increases (20ss'o of total Cr(V)) with increasing temperature of evacuation. Average oxidation state of Cr after NO adsorption This was measured in special redox cycles, illustrated in Fig. 6 and performed as follows. First, the ZC0.8(773) sample was submitted to the s.o. treatment (n = 5.5), reduced with CO at 623 K (n = 2.5), exposed to NO at RT for 3 h, and evacuated by slowly increasing the temperature (in 3 h) from RT to 773 K. After the latter evacuation, the sample was titrated with 02 at 773 K. From the OZ equivalents consumed, corresponding to a/Cr=1.3, n = 4.2 was calculated (n = 5.5-1.3 = 4.2). Second, the sample was once more reduced with CO at 623 K (e/Cr=3.0, n= 2.5), exposed to NO and evacuated as above. After the evacuation, the sample was titrated with CO at 623 K. From the CO equivalents consumed, corresponding to a/Cr=1.7, n=4.2 is calculated (n = 2.5 + 1.7 = 4.2); namely, the same value as above. Finally, the sample was once more heated with OZ at 773 K, from which n = 5.5 was determined. The latter result shows the full reversibility of the redox cycle. Discussion Having reported under Results the spectroscopic features and the assignments of the IR bands and ESR spectra, the Discussion will focus on the surface chemistry processes taking place upon adsorption of OZ or NO on the CrO.,/Zr02 samples, either in the oxidized state or reduced to the desired extent. Another aspect to be considered is the nature of sites active for the H2-D2 equilibration and hydrogenation reactions, previously investigated on the same catalysts [9; 12]. The titration of CrCf) with OZ at 195 K The effects of oxygen adsorption are considered first. For an understanding of this surface process, the following facts must be considered: (i) the s.o. sample only contains Cr(VI) and Cr(V) species in nearly equal amounts as 67 shown by n = 5.5 [ 9, 10 ], (ii) relying on ESR (Fig. 3) and IR evidence (10), Cr(V) is preferentially reduced to Cr(III) in the early stages of the reduction with CO, (iii) at higher extents of reduction (e /Cr > 1), Cr(VI) is also reduced to Cr(II) [10], and (iv) upon addition of OZ at 195 K or at RT, all Cr(II) is oxidized to Cr(VI), on IR evidence [ 10 ], whereas only a fraction of Cr(III) is oxidized to Cr(V) on both IR [10] and ESR evidence (Fig. 3 and [9, 13].) Based on these facts, the following model can be proposed and tested thereafter. The model assumes that the reduction of Cr(V) to Cr(III) and that of Cr(VI) to Cr(II) are two independent and strictly consecutive processes. Specifically, Cr(V) is only reduced to Cr(III) when the reduction is performed in the range from a/Cr= 0 to 1 (A = 5.5 to 4.5), and Cr(VI) is thereafter reduced to Cr(II), in the range a/Cr=1 to 3 (n= 4.5 to 2.5). The model also assumes that Cr(II) only is oxidized to CrM by the adsorption of OZ at 195 K on the reduced sample. In accord with the model, the dotted line of Fig. 11 has been calculated from the equation (e/Cr')o2 = (e/Cr"'),co in which (e/Cr")oz is the electron equivalents per Cr(II) calculated from the OZ molecules adsorbed at 195 K, and (e/Cr"')co is the electron equivalents per Cr(VI) calculated from the CO molecules consumed during the relevant reduction. The experimental points (from the data of Fig. 2, recalculated according to the model) axe seen to fall slightly above the calculated line. The fair agreement with the model suggests that the adsorption of OZ at 195 K is indeed a titration of the Cr(II) present in the reduced sample. The fact that the experimental points are somewhat higher with respect to the dotted line is accounted for by the simultaneous oxidation of some Cr(III) to Cr(V), however modest, which is in fact detected by ESR. NO redox reactions and the nitrosyls of Cr(II) and Cr(Ill) The dismutation of NO to N20 and nitrites (and/or nitrates) is the main reaction observed with the pure Zr02 support, heated in either OZ or CO. On the s.o. CrOx/ Zr02 sample, the dismutation is nearly absent and the NO oxidation accompanied by some reduction of Cr(V) to Cr(III) is the main redox process occurring, as shown by both ESR and IR data. On ESR evidence, 25'0 of Cr(V) undergoes reduction. On IR evidence, about 40% of Cr(V) undergoes reduction, and mono- and dinitrosyls of Cr(III) are formed. The reduction is, however, reversible, as Cr(V) is fully recovered upon desorption at 423 K. These latter results also show that some caution is required when using the NO molecule as a probe, since the molecule itself can yield various redox reactions upon adsorption at RT and/or evacuation even at mild temperatures (< 423 K). On the CrOx/Zr02 sample reduced to n = 2.5 (CI(H) and Cr(III) in nearly equal amounts [9, 10, 14]), mono- and dinitrosyls of Cr(H) and Cr(III) are formed on NO adsorption at RT. Some oxidation of Cr(II) to Cr(VI) (llg'o) is already observed at RT. The oxidation proceeds further upon evacuation of NO at progressively increasing temperature, reaching 90% at 423 K. The oxidation mainly involves Cr(II), as confirmed by ESR which shows that only a small fraction (20'0) of Cr(V) is recovered. In agreement with ESR and IR results, a value of n = 4.2 is determined from redox experiments performed on the sample after NO evacuation. From n=4.2, it is calculated that 93% of Cr(II) is oxidized to Cr(VI), in substantial agreement with the value obtained by IR. The reaction with H20 of the CrOx/Zr02 sample, previously reduced with CO, oxidizes Cr(H) to Cr(III) selectively [9, 10]. Only the mono- and dinitrosyls of Cr(IH) are in fact observed on adsorption of NO on the ZC sample, previously reacted with HZO at 853 K. On the subsequent desorption of NO at increasing temperature some Cr(V) is restored but not Cr(VI). The state of the surface of the ZC samples after adsorption of NO is further illustrated with the aid of data reported in Table 2. The Table reports the intensities of nitrosyls and nitrites and the relevant pretreatments after which these surface species were observed by IR. The concentration of nitrites is seen to be rather insensitive to the nature of the pretreatment, TABLE 2 Integrated intensities (cm-') of IR bands of nitrosyls and nitrites Treatment' Integrated intensity (cm-') nitrosyls nitrites (range 1930-1650 cm-') (range 1250-1100 cm-') 1. 02 at 923 K 67 53 2. 02 at 923 K+CO at 623 K 309 41 3. as above+ H20 at 853 K 4. as in 2 + evac. of NO at 423 K 132 55 "Sample treated as indicated, before exposure to NO (20 torr) for 3 h. 69 therefore suggesting that the chelating nitrites generated by the redox reaction with NO very likely do not involve chromium ions but rather sites of the Zr02 matrix, as already mentioned above. By way of contrast, the intensity of bands from nitrosyls depends strongly on the pretreatment of the sample. The finding that the highest concentration of nitrosyls is detected in the reduced ZC samples is accounted for by the fact that all the chromium of these samples has been reduced to Cr(II) and Cr(III), which both yield nitrosyls on NO adsorption. Reasons for the lower concentrations measured (i) on the ZC sample after s.o. and (ii) on the reduced one from which NO has been desorbed at 423 K, are also straightforward. Namely, (i) the small amount of Cr(III) arising from reduction with NO of Cr(V) is the only species capable of nitrosyl formation in the s.o. sample and (ii) Cr(III) only can lead to the formation of nitrosyls after evacuation of NO at 423 K, since Cr(II) is oxidized to Cr(VI) during the evacuation itself. The lower concentration of nitrosyls observed when the reduced sample is afterward reacted with H20 requires an explanation. As already mentioned above, the reaction with H20 oxidizes Cr(II) to Cr(IIl) selectively [9, 101, without affecting the preexisting Cr(III) (Cr(IIl)-S, on ESR evidence [ 10, 141). The Cr(III) arising from the oxidation of Cr(II) with H20 (Cr(III)-/3, distinct from Cr(III)-S on ESR evidence) could, in principle, yield nitrosyls on NO adsorption, and therefore the same or similar concentrations of nitrosyls would be expected on both the CO-reduced and the CO-reduced plus H20 reacted samples. However, it has been previously found that the Cr(III) produced from the oxidation of Cr(II) with H20 enters into Cr(III)-clusters, whose dimension increases with increasing temperature of reaction with H20. Specifically, Cr(III)-/3, Cr(III)-ss" and a-Cr203 were indeed identified by ESR with increasing temperature of the reaction with H20, in that order [ 141. It is therefore likely that in these chromia-like particles most of the chromium is not exposed on the surface and therefore not available for the adsorption of NO. The rather high values of the ratios NO/Cr (1.7 to 2.0 NO molecules per total reduced Cr atom, either Cr(II) or Cr(III)) and OZ/Cr(II) (ca. four electron per Cr(II) atom) show that both these chromium species are well dispersed on the surface of the reduced CrO.,O2 samples. On the whole, the results presented in this investigation strengthen the earlier statement that Cr(VI) and CrM are stabilized in the oxidized ZC samples and Cr(II) and Cr(III) in the reduced ones [9, 10, 131. The unambiguous separation of the surface chromium species in two redox couples, specifically Cr(Vi)/ Cr(II) on one side and Cr(V) /Cr(II) on the other, suggests the presence of two distinct precursors on the surface, differing by the chromium nuclearity. The two precursors are formed during either the impregnation of the catalyst or the subsequent heating in OZ at 773 K. At present, the exact nature of these species cannot be assessed. It can be suggested, however, that chromates and polychromates should be involved, as reported in the previous IR investigation of the ZC samples [ 101, and recently in a Raman investigation of CrOx/AIZOg [251. 70 The active sites for hydrogenations The catalytic activity of the CrOx/Zr02 system for the H2-D2 equilibration and hydrogenation of propene has been reported previously [ 9, 12 ]. From the catalytic behaviour and poisoning experiments with OZ and H20, it was possible to conclude that (i) isolated Cr(III) ions arising from the reduction of mononuclear Cr(V) are the active sites for both reactions, (ii) Cr(II), either alone or in combination with Cr(III), is inactive when supported on Zr02 and (iii) coordinative unsaturation is an essential factor. With regard to the coordinative requirements which make chromium active for the activation of hydrogen, the results presented here allow further discussion. Or heating with H20, not only is the catalytic activity unaffected, as observed previously [9, 121, but the ability of the Cr(III) species to yield dinitrosyls is also maintained, as testified in the present investigation by III. By way of contrast, the Cr(III) arising from the oxidation of Cr(II) with H20 neither contributes to the catalytic activity (otherwise an increase in catalytic activity would have been observed after the treatment with H20), nor is it capable of NO adsorption. In contrast to the Cr(III) arising from reduction of Cr(V), that arising from the oxidation of Cr(II) with H20 tends to cluster, leading to chromia-like particles, as shown by ESR [ 10, 14 ]. These results stress the point that not all Cr(III) ions are active, but only those possessing the proper coordination. The presence of two coordinative vacancies on the chromium site is not, however, a guarantee of activity in catalysis, as shown by the Cr(II) site on Zr02 which leads to dinitrosyls upon NO adsorption and is, nevertheless, catalytically inactive. Chimica Inorganica, Chimica Fisica e Chimica dei Materiali, Università di Torino, Turin Italy The adsorption of O2 at 195 K and that of NO at 298 K on CrO x /ZrO2 samples have been investigated by the double isotherm method. The nature of the surface species formed before and after adsorption has been studied by means of IR and ESR spectroscopies. Prior to O2 or NO adsorption, CrO x /ZrO2 samples were heated in O2 at 773 K (average oxidation number of Cr, n =5.5) and reduced with CO at 423 to 623 K to controlled extents ( n =5.5 to 2.5). The results show that the adsorption of O2 at 195 K oxidizes to Cr(VI) the Cr(II) present in the sample after the reduction. The oxidation of Cr(II) to Cr(VI) is quantitative and nearly selective. Only a small fraction of Cr(III), also present in the reduced sample, is oxidized to Cr(V) (ESR, γ-signal). The adsorption of NO on the sample heated in O2 yields mono- and dinitrosyls of Cr(III), arising from the reduction of Cr(V). The reduction of Cr(V) to Cr(III) is evidenced by both ESR and IR data. The adsorption of NO on the reduced sample ( n =2.5) leads, on average, to 1.7 to 2.0 NO molecules adsorbed per Cr atom. In the same conditions, dinitrosyls and mononitrosyls of Cr(II) and Cr(III) are formed, in addition to N2O and nitrites (and/or nitrates). Upon evacuation of the latter sample at 423 K, the adsorbed NO oxidizes most of the Cr(II) to Cr(VI) ( n =4.2) and, in fact, the nitrosyls of Cr(III) are the only species detected by IR on NO re-admission after the evacuation treatment. Blank experiments on pure ZrO2 show that the dismutation of NO leading to N2O and nitrites (and/or nitrates) takes place on sites of the ZrO2 support. When the reduced sample is further reacted with H2O at 853 K, only the dinitrosyls and mononitrosyls of Cr(III) are detected upon exposure to NO, since the reaction with H2O at 853 K selectively oxidizes the Cr(II) to chromia-like species. It is suggested that coordinatively unsaturated Cr(III) ions, two vacancies at least on IR evidence, are the active sites for the hydrogenation of propene and H2D2 equilibration reactions, previously investigated on the same CrO x /ZrO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The adsorption of O2 at 195 K and that of NO at 298 K on CrO x /ZrO2 samples have been investigated by the double isotherm method. The nature of the surface species formed before and after adsorption has been studied by means of IR and ESR spectroscopies. Prior to O2 or NO adsorption, CrO x /ZrO2 samples were heated in O2 at 773 K (average oxidation number of Cr, n =5.5) and reduced with CO at 423 to 623 K to controlled extents ( n =5.5 to 2.5). The results show that the adsorption of O2 at 195 K oxidizes to Cr(VI) the Cr(II) present in the sample after the reduction. The oxidation of Cr(II) to Cr(VI) is quantitative and nearly selective. Only a small fraction of Cr(III), also present in the reduced sample, is oxidized to Cr(V) (ESR, γ-signal). The adsorption of NO on the sample heated in O2 yields mono- and dinitrosyls of Cr(III), arising from the reduction of Cr(V). The reduction of Cr(V) to Cr(III) is evidenced by both ESR and IR data. The adsorption of NO on the reduced sample ( n =2.5) leads, on average, to 1.7 to 2.0 NO molecules adsorbed per Cr atom. In the same conditions, dinitrosyls and mononitrosyls of Cr(II) and Cr(III) are formed, in addition to N2O and nitrites (and/or nitrates). Upon evacuation of the latter sample at 423 K, the adsorbed NO oxidizes most of the Cr(II) to Cr(VI) ( n =4.2) and, in fact, the nitrosyls of Cr(III) are the only species detected by IR on NO re-admission after the evacuation treatment. Blank experiments on pure ZrO2 show that the dismutation of NO leading to N2O and nitrites (and/or nitrates) takes place on sites of the ZrO2 support. When the reduced sample is further reacted with H2O at 853 K, only the dinitrosyls and mononitrosyls of Cr(III) are detected upon exposure to NO, since the reaction with H2O at 853 K selectively oxidizes the Cr(II) to chromia-like species. It is suggested that coordinatively unsaturated Cr(III) ions, two vacancies at least on IR evidence, are the active sites for the hydrogenation of propene and H2D2 equilibration reactions, previously investigated on the same CrO x /ZrO2 catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The adsorption of O2 and NO on CrO x /ZrO2 catalysts, as investigated by IR and ESR spectroscopies
